abstract: The company’s board said it would investigate allegations of sexual harassment against Mr. Moonves that were detailed in a New Yorker article.

abstract: The financing reflects the technology’s embrace by Beijing, which has created a better environment for companies to test it than in the West.

abstract: An attack hit a joint NATO and Afghan patrol north of Kabul. A Taliban assault continued in Uruzgan Province. And an Afghan soldier died trying to stop a bombing in Jalalabad.

abstract: Amazon said its Whole Foods stores would let customers order groceries online and pick them up in person. Walmart already offers that service at nearly 1,800 stores.

headline: ‘There’s No Law’: Political Crisis Sends Nicaraguans Fleeing
abstract: Dread and anxiety pervade the Central American country after a crackdown by Daniel Ortega’s government.

headline: He’s 9, a Chess Prodigy and Must Leave the U.K., Officials Say
abstract: The family of Shreyas Royal, who was born in India, is fighting to stay in Britain once the father’s work visa runs out.

headline: Trump’s Ancestral Village Abounds With His Relatives. Few Admit a Link.
abstract: The German village of Kallstadt doesn’t like to advertise its connection to President Trump. “The topic is too controversial,” a tourism official said.

headline: Ohio Teacher Sets Record for Rowing Alone Across the Atlantic
abstract: A teacher from Cincinnati set a record for a west-east crossing after coping with a dozen capsizes, damaged electronics and difficulties eating.

headline: Customers Used to Come for a Loan. Now, They Come for Pizza.
abstract: A downward trend in banking is opening up real estate opportunities as investors convert former branches to other uses, including churches, pharmacies and pizza parlors.

headline: Ikea Opens First India Store, Tweaking Products but Not the Vibe
abstract: The Swedish furniture giant opens in Hyderabad, India, this week. To appeal to customers, it is cutting prices, offering assembly and selling samosas.

headline: More Than 100 Cars Burned in Mass Arson Attack in Sweden
abstract: The police said the vehicle fires had been coordinated by groups of young men using social media, but the authorities are at a loss to explain why.

headline: The Mobile Virtual Network Operator Will Connect You Now
abstract: What’s a M.V.N.O.? It’s typically a smaller wireless carrier that offers inexpensive service plans but gets its network signals from a bigger company.

headline: Monsoon Flooding Kills 6 in Pakistani City
abstract: Much of the eastern city of Lahore, home to 6 million people, is submerged.

headline: Lyft Follows Uber Into Bike-Sharing Lane, Buying Owner of CitiBike
abstract: The ride-hailing company agreed to buy the core operations of Motivate, which offers bicycle rentals in eight United States cities.

headline: Philippine Mayor Who Shamed Drug Suspects Is Killed During Flag Ceremony
abstract: Antonio Halili had his police force round up drug suspects and parade them in Tanauan City in a “walk of shame” campaign. He was later accused of protecting drug syndicates.

headline: Theresa May Says Trump Told Her to ‘Sue the E.U.’ in Brexit Talks
abstract: In her comments to the BBC, the British prime minister appeared to be pushing back against President Trump, who had criticized her for ignoring his suggestion.

headline: Banks Report Earnings, and Google Faces Antitrust Fines
abstract: The Fed chairman will testify before panels in the House and Senate, and the Commerce Department will holding hearings on auto tariffs.

headline: Amazon’s Curious Case of the $2,630.52 Used Paperback
abstract: Booksellers on the online marketplace are charging thousands for books that normally sell for a few dollars. Authors are perplexed — and annoyed.

headline: Major Chain in Canada Pulls Ivanka Trump’s Clothing
abstract: The Hudson’s Bay Company, Canada’s largest non-discount department store, ended online sales of the brand and will not order more for stores.

headline: Revealed: The People Behind an Anti-Breitbart Twitter Account
abstract: No longer anonymously run, Sleeping Giants continues its mission of alerting companies to where their digital ads end up.

headline: Brazil’s Military Strides Into Politics, by the Ballot or by Force
abstract: Scores of former officers are running for office. And if the ballot box doesn’t work, some former officials warn of a possible military coup.

headline: Wave After Wave of Garbage Hits the Dominican Republic
abstract: The Caribbean nation is known for sapphire seas and ivory beaches, but it is grappling with sludgy trash washing up on some famous shores.

headline: U.S.-Funded Broadcaster Directed Ads to Americans
abstract: Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty is mostly restricted by law from promoting its content in the United States except on request.

headline: Mugabe Has Left, but His Legacy Haunts Zimbabwe’s Election
abstract: The July 30 vote will be the first since the resignation of Robert G. Mugabe, Zimbabwe’s leader since independence.

headline: Should We Be Anticipating War With Iran? No, but It Could Get Nasty
abstract: The military capabilities of the United States dwarf those of Iran, and the Iranians know it. Still, they will not back down from a confrontation.

headline: British Man Poisoned by Novichok Is Released From Hospital
abstract: Charlie Rowley and his partner were sickened on July 1 by a Russian nerve agent. His partner died, but he survived.

headline: Pompeo, at U.N., Says North Korean Leader Must Keep Vow to Denuclearize
abstract: Secretary of State Mike Pompeo, visiting the United Nations, vowed that there would be no letup in sanctions on North Korea until its leader does ‘what he promised the world he would do.’

headline: Insider Attack in Afghanistan Exposes Risks for Advisers at Center of Trump Strategy
abstract: Officials are investigating whether an Army training brigade that is a top Pentagon priority had enough security personnel to protect it from partnered Afghan forces.

headline: How Consumers Can Resist Companies’ Market Power
abstract: Companies try to lock people into buying their products without comparison shopping. But consumers can fight back, an economist says.

headline: Australians Protest Five Years of Offshore Detention Policy
abstract: In cities across Australia demonstrators denounced five years of a policy that has left thousands detained on remote Pacific islands.

headline: In South Africa’s ‘Mafia-Like’ Taxi Industry, 11 Die in Latest Attack
abstract: The victims were drivers for a Johannesburg minibus taxi association, the latest casualties in a decades-long battle over taxi routes that has claimed hundreds of lives.

headline: The Biggest Spender of Political Ads on Facebook? President Trump
abstract: A new study based on Facebook data provides a picture of who is placing political ads on the social network ahead of the midterm elections. President Trump tops the list.

headline: Microsoft Emerges as Clear No. 2 in Cloud Computing
abstract: The cloud computing market is booming, but companies are leery of relying on one tech giant. That is helping Microsoft.

headline: Montenegro: What to Know About the Tiny NATO Ally Trump Slighted
abstract: The newest NATO member state is in the spotlight, thanks to comments made by President Trump.

headline: Tensions Escalate Between Greece and Russia, With Macedonia in the Middle
abstract: As a war of words sharpened between Athens and Moscow, the Russian foreign minister canceled a visit to Athens.

headline: Trump Nominee Is Mastermind of Anti-Union Legal Campaign
abstract: A conservative lawyer chosen to head a federal agency has spent months bringing cases that could bankrupt public-employee unions in several states.

headline: North Korea Criticizes ‘Gangster-Like’ U.S. Attitude After Talks With Mike Pompeo
abstract: North Korea’s Foreign Ministry accused the Trump administration of pushing a “gangster-like demand for denuclearization.” But Secretary of State Mike Pompeo called the talks “productive.”

headline: The Pursuit of $1 Trillion: Amazon Closes In on Apple
abstract: The race to surpass the symbolic market cap is Apple’s to lose, but Amazon is increasingly giving it some stiff competition.

headline: Soon Only One Blockbuster Will Be Left in the United States
abstract: The planned closings of two Blockbuster video stores in Alaska will leave one store in central Oregon as the last one in the United States.

headline: Israel Passes ‘National Home’ Law, Drawing Ire of Arabs
abstract: The legislation alters the status of Arabic from an official language to a “special” one, and says the right to national self-determination rests solely with the Jewish people.

headline: Trump Voters May Be the Biggest Losers From Trump’s Auto Tariffs
abstract: European auto manufacturers are among the biggest employers in some Republican strongholds.

headline: North Koreans Are No-Shows at Meeting to Discuss U.S. Soldiers’ Remains
abstract: Talks on returning American troops killed in the Korean War did not take place as planned. But it was unclear whether U.S. officials had been deliberately stood up.

headline: After 20-Year ‘State of War,’ a Flight With Champagne and Roses
abstract: Affirming a breakthrough peace deal, a plane flew from Ethiopia to Eritrea, carrying politicians, artists, journalists and potential investors.

headline: How 2 Media Moguls’ Once-Warm Friendship Turned Frigid
abstract: The legal wrangling between CBS, Viacom and the Redstone family provides a behind-the-scenes view into how quickly a powerful business alliance can fray.

headline: Starbucks to Stop Using Disposable Plastic Straws by 2020
abstract: The retailer, which has more than 28,000 stores worldwide, says the decision will eliminate more than 1 billion straws a year.

headline: Picking an iPad as a Portable Photo Studio
abstract: Apple has a range of models in its tablet line, but you may not need the most expensive one to suit your image-editing needs.

headline: Iran’s Top Banker Is Dismissed in Shake-Up as U.S. Sanctions Take a Toll
abstract: The head of Iran’s central bank since 2013 was fired as the country grappled with a weakened currency, tied in part to renewed U.S. sanctions.

headline: Wages Are Rising in Europe. But Economists Are Puzzled.
abstract: Increases in worker pay have given the European Central Bank confidence to end its main stimulus measure. Yet there is no consensus on why it took so long.

headline: When Troubleshooters Run Into Trouble
abstract: Microsoft has a collection of little programs that try to fix problems on your Windows PC, but depending on your system, the success rate can be hit or miss.

headline: New Zealand to Australia: Get Your Own Flag
abstract: “We had a flag that we’ve had for a long time, copied by Australia,” New Zealand’s acting prime minister said. “And they should actually change their flag and honor the fact that we got there first.”

headline: NXP’s Chief Criticizes China After Qualcomm Deal Collapses
abstract: Richard Clemmer, NXP’s chief executive, blamed Chinese authorities for withholding approval of a $44 billion deal with Qualcomm amid a trade war between Washington and Beijing.

headline: What’s Behind a Pitch for the Little-Guy Investor? Big Money Interests
abstract: The newly formed Main Street Investors Coalition says it wants to protect the rights of mom-and-pop investors. But its main complaint seems to be financial firms’ social consciousness.

headline: United Nations Leader Warns of a Cash Shortage
abstract: Secretary General António Guterres said “delayed contributions” had caused a cash shortfall “unlike those we have experienced previously.”

headline: Ways to Lighten Your Data Load
abstract: A browser that’s set to compress or block images, ads and other bandwidth-hogging parts of a web page can save you megabytes.

headline: Nicaragua Clergy, Siding With Protesters, Becomes ‘Terrible Enemy’ of Ortega
abstract: The government “has declared war on the church,” said one opposition member. President Daniel Ortega responded that leaders in the church are part of the “coup-plotters” working against him.

headline: Microsoft Employees Question C.E.O. Over Company’s Contract With ICE
abstract: Microsoft employees presented Satya Nadella, the chief executive, with a petition signed by over 300,000 people that called on the company to cancel its contract with ICE.

headline: New Round of U.S.-China Trade War Rattles Global Markets
abstract: The prospect of an intensifying clash with the Trump administration is adding to pressures that have sent Chinese stocks into a bear market.

headline: I Used Apple’s New Controls to Limit a Teenager’s iPhone Time (and It Worked!)
abstract: Apple’s new parental controls cut a teenager’s iPhone use in half. It wasn’t as effective on our personal tech columnist.

headline: Soccer Players and Their Coach Are on the Mend, Thailand Says
abstract: “They took care of each other well in the cave,” a public health official said of the 12 boys and their coach, a day after the last of them were rescued.

headline: Kushner’s Firm Deepens Ties to Those With Business in Washington
abstract: The family company of Jared Kushner, President Trump’s son-in-law and senior adviser, is doing deals with investors who have a lot riding on federal decisions.

headline: Comcast and Fox Engage in Bidding War for Control of Sky
abstract: Comcast’s new offer for Sky values the company at about 26 billion pounds, or $34 billion, topping an earlier bid from 21st Century Fox.

headline: The Benefits (and Limits) of Using Tech to Plan a Wedding
abstract: Our newly engaged tech columnist tried to use tech to plan his wedding. He was immediately overwhelmed by the complexity of the process.

headline: Russia, Accused of Faking News, Unfurls Its Own ‘Fake News’ Bill
abstract: A measure in Parliament would fine social networks about $800,000 for posts deemed factually inaccurate. Critics say it could limit freedom of speech online.

headline: Attacks on Roma Force Ukraine to Confront an Old Ethnic Enmity
abstract: The assaults by nationalist groups pose a dilemma for Kiev, which is beholden to many of the same paramilitaries for their role fighting the Russian incursion in the east.

headline: Shonda Rhimes Describes Her Grand Netflix Ambitions
abstract: The star producer reveals the eight shows she plans to make for the streaming service, which wooed her away from ABC with a nine-figure deal.

headline: With Brexit Deadlocked, Britain Stares Over a Cliff
abstract: Another week of infighting has left Theresa May besieged, her E.U. withdrawal plan on life support. No one seems to know what happens next.

headline: ‘Your Concern Is Human Rights, Mine Is Human Lives,’ Duterte Says in Fiery Speech
abstract: The Philippine president was denied a chance to announce a deal with a Muslim rebel group. Instead, he doubled down on his deadly war on drugs.

headline: Facebook and YouTube Give Alex Jones a Wrist Slap
abstract: A Facebook suspension and a YouTube probation, for videos that violated policies, followed weeks of controversy over Mr. Jones, who oversees Infowars.

headline: Catalog of Fania Records, the Motown of Latin Music, Is Sold
abstract: The independent Concord Music bought the catalog of the New York salsa label that defined the genre in the 1960s and ’70s in a deal estimated at $30 million.

headline: What Stays on Facebook and What Goes? The Social Network Cannot Answer
abstract: Asked about the kind of content Facebook keeps up and the kind it removes, company executives from Mark Zuckerberg on down have been comically tripped up in their responses.

headline: Employee Uprisings Sweep Many Tech Companies. Not Twitter.
abstract: Many tech workers are forcing their employers to reconsider how their products are being used by the federal government. When will that activism begin at Twitter?

headline: A Taste of Lime: Uber Invests in an Electric Scooter Company
abstract: The investment in Lime, an electric scooter start-up, is the latest effort by Uber to expand beyond ride-hailing.

headline: Inside the Mating Rituals of Brands and Online Stars
abstract: With deals collectively worth billions of dollars at stake, the pressure is on advertisers and viral performers on sites like YouTube and Instagram to find the right match.

headline: British Roll Out Trump’s Political Idol: Winston Churchill
abstract: It’s no accident that Mr. Trump began his visit to England by having dinner at Blenheim Palace, birthplace of Winston Churchill.

headline: Broadcom Reaches Nearly $19 Billion Deal to Buy CA Technologies
abstract: The acquisition would be Broadcom’s first big move since its $117 billion bid for Qualcomm was blocked by the Trump administration in March.

headline: Battling Fake Accounts, Twitter to Slash Millions of Followers
abstract: Twitter will begin removing tens of millions of suspicious accounts from follower numbers, signaling a major new effort to fight fraud and restore trust on the platform.

headline: A Sedate Dinner, but a Bombshell Interview, for Trump’s U.K. Visit
abstract: President Trump left the NATO summit meeting in Brussels for a visit to Britain. He was greeted with pomp and protest.
